question: When examining the "ECG Signal – Baseline Wander Contamination" plot in the simulation, baseline wander is visually identified as:

answers.a: Very sharp, random spikes scattered throughout the signal
answers.b: The entire ECG waveform slowly drifting up and down over a period of several seconds
answers.c: Only the R-peak becoming progressively taller
answers.d: The signal becoming completely flat with no waveform variation

question: After applying a high-pass Butterworth filter with a cutoff frequency of ~0.5 Hz, the most expected result is:

answers.b: Reduction of baseline drift while preserving ECG morphology

question: Increasing the order of a Butterworth filter mainly results in:

answers.b: Sharper roll-off and better stopband attenuation

question: Why is a 0.5–40 Hz band-pass filter widely used in ECG preprocessing?

answers.b: It preserves ECG information while removing low- and high-frequency noise

question: When designing a window-based FIR filter using the windowing technique, how do the main-lobe width and side-lobe level of the chosen window function primarily affect the filter’s frequency response?

answers.a: Main-lobe width controls computational speed, while side-lobe level determines filter stability
answers.b: Main-lobe width determines the sharpness of the transition band, while side-lobe level controls stopband attenuation and spectral leakage
answers.c: Main-lobe width fixes the cutoff frequency exactly, while side-lobe level sets the filter order
answers.d: Both main-lobe width and side-lobe level affect only the phase response of the filter
